titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Poindexter Gallery Records, 1931-1985, bulk 1955-1978, in the Archives of American Art AAA.poingall
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Alexandra Krensky
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-12-20T15:37-0500

did.abstract: The records of the Poindexter Gallery measure 6.8 linear feet and date from 1931-1985 with the bulk of the materials dating from 1955-1978 when the gallery was active. The majority of the collection consists of artists’ files documenting the gallery’s relationships with its artists, including exhibitions, and containing a wide variety of materials, including photographs. Also found are the "desk files" kept by the gallery’s founder, Elinor Poindexter; correspondence; and financial and legal records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 5 series.

list.item: Series 1: Elinor Poindexter Desk Files, 1947-1969 (Box 1, 8 folders)
Series 3: Artists’ Files, 1931-1983, undated (Box 2-5, 2.4 linear feet)
Series 4: Financial and Legal Files, 1955-1985 (Box 5-6, 1.0 linear feet)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Poindexter Gallery was founded in 1955 in New York City by Elinor Poindexter. The gallery specialized in sculpture, abstract, and figurative art and featured the works of such artists as Richard Diebenkorn, Jules Olitski, Nell Blaine, William de Kooning, Giorgio Spaventa, Franz Kline, Earl Kerkam, Milton Resnick and Robert De Niro, among others. The Poindexter Gallery closed in 1978.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was minimally processed, arranged, and described by Alexandra Krensky in 2013 with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution's Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

The goal for minimal-level processing at the Archives of American Art is to provide access to collections as quickly as possible while maintaining our high standards for arrangement, description and preservation. Generally, materials are minimally rearranged, existing folder titles are retained, and all materials are rehoused in acid-free folders and boxes. Staples and other fasteners are not removed, but materials are removed from binders or damaged binding when necessary.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Poindexter Gallery records were donated over a period from 1968-1978 by the Poindexter Gallery via owners Elinor Poindexter and art director Harold Fondren. A 2006 accession was donated by Christie Poindexter Dennis, daughter of Elinor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Poindexter Gallery records, 1931-1985, bulk 1955-1978, Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Among other resources relating to the Poindexter Gallery records in the Archives of American Art is an oral history with gallery owner, Elinor Poindexter, conducted by Paul Cummings on September 9, 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records of the Poindexter Gallery measure 6.8 linear feet and date from 1931-1985 with the bulk of the materials dating from 1955-1978 when the gallery was active. The majority of the collection consists of artists’ files documenting the gallery’s relationships with its artists, including exhibitions, and containing a wide variety of materials, including photographs. Also found are the "desk files" kept by the gallery’s founder, Elinor Poindexter; correspondence; and financial and legal records.

Elinor Poindexter's desk files consist of documents she kept as a reference for both her personal needs and gallery business. Correspondence is with artists, museums, colleges and universities, and art institutes. Notable correspondents include Worcester Art Museum, Corcoran Gallery of Art, Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Solomon Guggenheim Museum, Denver Art Museum, Yale University, Oberlin College, University of Arizona, the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University, Smithsonian Institution, and the Montana Historical Association. Additional correspondence is found throughout desk files and artists’ files as well.

Artists’ files are found for artists represented by the gallery, or in whom the gallery took an interest. Contents of the files vary, but may contain correspondence, photographs, sales records, exhibition files, and printed materials. There is extensive material relating to artists Richard Diebenkorn, William de Kooning, Giorgio Spaventa, Robert De Niro, Earl Kerkam, Franz Kline, Milton Resnick, Eleanor Dickinson, Paul Harris, Jules Olitski, among others.

The remainder of the collection consists of financial and legal files containing sales inventories and receipts, price lists, bills, loan agreements, and documents pertaining to the estate of Giorgio Spaventa, as well as photographic materials consisting of prints, negatives, slides and color transparencies of artwork.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Poindexter Gallery records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

controlaccess.corpname: Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)
controlaccess.subject: Art galleries, Commercial -- New York (State)-- New York
Art, Modern -- 20th century

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by original file name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Elinor Poindexter desk files contain clippings, press releases, Elinor’s biography, an index of articles about artists, savings bank documents, notes and personal files, legal documents, invoices, and miscellaneous correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence chronicles the gallery’s relationships with different artists, including artists who exhibited there, as well as artists who they took an interest in. The series also includes correspondence between the Poindexter Gallery and other art galleries, museums, and colleges and universities. Notable correspondents include Worcester Art Museum, Corcoran Gallery of Art, Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Solomon Guggenheim Museum, Denver Art Museum, Yale University, Oberlin College, University of Arizona, the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University, Smithsonian Institution, and the Montana Historical Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The artists’ files represent the bulk of the records and are files that were created by the Poindexter Gallery in order to keep track of artists whose work they exhibited and whose work they were interested in. Among those represented in the series are the artists Richard Diebenkorn, William de Kooning, Giorgio Spaventa, Robert De Niro, Earl Kerkam, Franz Kline, Milton Resnick, Eleanor Dickinson, Paul Harris, Jules Olitski. Materials included in the artists’ files are correspondence, photographs of artwork, sales records, exhibition files, and printed materials. Due to the nature of the material as reference files, some of the artists’ files predate and postdate the dates that Poindexter Gallery was open.

did.unittitle: Condon, Rudolph, Writings and Printed Material
Diebenkorn, Richard, Magazine and Newspaper Clippings
Harris, Paul, Photographs and Negatives of Works
Hopkins, Budd, Magazine and Newspaper Articles
Kerkam, Earl, Newspaper and Magazine Clippings
Natkin, Robert, Magazine and Newspaper Reviews
Olitski, Jules, Inventories and Price List

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by folder title and thereunder chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Financial and legal files document sales made by the gallery as well as day-to-day fiscal and legal matters. Materials include invoices, price lists, sales receipts, bills, inventories, and loan agreements. Also included are court papers regarding a claim brought against the gallery by the estate of Giorgio Spaventa after his death in 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographic materials consist of prints, developed negatives, color transparencies and slides of artwork by artists who were represented by Poindexter Gallery or in whom the gallery took an interest. Among the artists heavily represented are Alfred Puhn, Nell Blaine, Richard Diebenkorn, Steven Sloman, and Manchouer Yekati. Photographic materials pertaining to artwork also appear in the artists’ files.
